title: BUILDING ACCORDING TO CODE
words:
Building According 
To Code

In 1992, Hurricane Andrew destroyed thousands of homes in South 
Florida. Yet
in an area where the wreckage looked like a war zone, one house 
remained
standing, still firmly anchored to its foundation.

When a reporter asked the homeowner why his house had not been blown 
away,
he replied, "I built this house myself. I also built it according to 
the
Florida state building code. When the code called for 2" x 6" roof 
trusses,
I used 2" x 6" roof trusses. I was told that a house built according 
to code
could withstand a hurricane-- and it did."

Jesus talked about the importance of building our lives on a solid
foundation. He said that the person who obeys His Word is like "a 
wise man
who built his house on the rock" (Matt. 7:24). If we build according 
to His
code of obedience, we will not be swept away when crises hit with
hurricane-like force. The tempests of temptation and the storms of 
suffering
will not be able to sweep us off a solid foundation of faith and 
obedience.
Adversity may come, yet because we have built according to the code 
of the
unshakable Rock, Jesus Christ, we can emerge with our character
strengthened.

Are we building our lives according to Jesus' code?

title: BUILDING ACCORDING TO CODE
words:
It is significant that Jesus ended the Sermon on the Mount with the 
parable
of the Wise and Foolish Builders. Throughout the long day Jesus had 
been
preaching to the vast multitude. They listened to him with amazement 
and
awe. But Jesus warned them that that was not enough. It is never 
enough
simply to listen to the words of Jesus, even though we may listen with
reverent approval. If His words are to have any genuine effect in our 
lives
we must not only hear them but also act upon them. We must 
incorporate them
in the events of our day-to-day living.

To drive the point home Jesus told the compelling story of two 
builders who
each built a home. Standing inside these homes, going from room to 
room,
there was little to no difference between. Even from the outside one 
might
say they were virtually indistinguishable from one another. But, said 
Jesus,
the foundations, one built upon the rock and the other upon sand. 
When Jesus
spoke about houses and foundations he knew what he was talking about. 
He was
a stonemason by trade and his family was most likely in the 
construction
business.

The people there, listening to Jesus' teaching, understood well the
significance of building upon rock verses sand. But very few people in
ancient Palestine wanted to live in the rocks. It meant grading the 
side of
a slope and hauling up materials. Living in the hills made for more
difficult travel. Water had to be toted and winter winds were colder. 
Most
people followed the path of least resistance and built along the 
riverbeds.
The scenery more pleasant, the water more conveniently located, and 
the
house was sheltered from the cold winds of winter. And though 
flooding was a
danger, most of the year the streams trickled pleasantly down the 
hillsides
into the river nearby.

But on rare occasions, perhaps only once a generation, the 100-year 
flood
would come. There would be a combination of an unusually heavy snow, 
a quick
spring thaw, a torrential downpour. The result was a vicious 
flashflood
which swept away everything in its path. Entire hamlets washed away. 
House
after house gone and great would be the fall.

That's the image drawn here in Matthew 7. It comes from the life of 
these
people gathered around Jesus on that day he delivered this sermon. 
Jesus was
not simply telling here what I call a preacher story. A preacher 
story is an
illustration that may very well fit the point that is being made, but 
one
that doesn't sound very believable. On the contrary, Jesus was 
talking about
a situation that was very real in the life of the people.

title: BURYING A BUSLOAD OF POLITICIANS
words:
Busload of Politicians 

A busload of politicians were driving down a country 
road when the bus suddenly ran off the road and crashed 
into an old farmer's field. 

The old farmer heard the tragic crash so he rushed over 
to investigate. He then began digging a large grave to 
bury the politicians. 

A few hours later, the local sheriff was driving past 
the farmer's field and noticed the bus wreck. He 
approached the old farmer and asked where all the 
politicians had gone. 

The old farmer explained that he'd gone ahead and 
buried all of them. 

"Were they ALL dead?" asked the puzzled sheriff. 

"Well, some of them said they weren't," said the old 
farmer, "but you know how them politicians lie."

title: BOOZE: PERHAPS WE SHOLD START BEING HONEST ABOUT IT TOO.
words:
Booze: 'Perhaps We Should Start Being Honest About It, Too'

ROSS MACKENZIE
TIMES-DISPATCH COLUMNIST  Jul 18, 2002

              When I went off to boarding school my physician father 
said, "Except for food, don't put anything into your mouth that isn't 
given to you by a doctor." The advice helped make that teen-ager a 
non-smoker. In college, it helped him avoid the peyote, mescalin, and 
marijuana that in the early Sixties were beginning to worm their way 
into the collegiate - and national - culture.

              It did not help with alcohol. Fraternity drink- ing 
bouts still are the stuff of legend, and even now a drink or two goes 
down rather nicely. This rare bit of personal history is set down 
here to inform the reader, prior to what follows, that the writer is 
not a total prig.

For the hour is at hand to talk about booze. It is insidiously 
everywhere. It's the elephant in the living room that most 
insistently refuse to notice.

YES, IT HAS been around for millennia. Yes, alcoholic merriment was 
rooted on college campuses at least as far back as the 12th Century, 
when a bunch of Oxford divinity students composed one of the most 
enduring drinking songs, "Gaudeamus Igitur." Yes, drinking was so bad 
on UVa's campus, causing student riots, that in the 1820s founder 
Thomas Jefferson urged that alcohol and other
"vicious irregularities" be banned.

Still, the impression - how to quantify it even in this age of 
quantification? - is that alcohol infuses this society to an extent 
rarely seen. Advertising glorifies it. Without it most parties bomb. 
The shelves of wineshops spill over with bottles from around the 
globe, and 
aaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaaq0cauamk'z-aaaa'pqaafrankenstein stores 
are not far behind. (Never mind the divine aroma; never mind the 
unique blend of barley and hops: We're talking here about
variant flavors of an addictive drug.)

With not much success, colleges across the land struggle to deal with 
the drinking "rite of passage." The latest effort is "social-norm 
marketing," extensively funded by brewers and others. Colleges having 
given up on trying to convince students that drinking can be 
dangerous, this is the nifty notion that pushing the health benefits 
of moderation (ah yes: "drinking, the healthy choice") is far better 
than
employing the scare tactics of abstinence - which suggests nothing 
quite so much as that the game is over.

And now the news columns and rumor mills are full of stories about 
the things high-schoolers and middle-schoolers are doing as a 
consequence of alcohol - to others and to themselves. Even as the 
experiments in combatting this scourge proliferate, the ages of those 
using alcohol descend.

LOOK AT the numbers.

Remember the campaigns to combat "binge drinking" on campus? A major 
study has found that on an average day four college students die in 
accidents involving alcohol. An additional 1,370 suffer injuries tied 
to drinking, and 192 are raped by their dates or sexually assaulted 
after drinking.

In the culture at large, let's see: According to the Justice 
Department, alcohol is a factor in one-fourth of aggravated assaults, 
one-third of sex crimes, one-half of homicides, and two-thirds of 
domestic violence cases. And there are those staggering numbers about 
the role of booze in highway maimings and deaths.

So as everybody knows, alcohol liberates anger. It promotes stupid 
behavior. It prevents learning. It drives its abusers down. It shreds 
emotions, it wounds, and it kills.

Yet we look the other way, give it a wink and a nod, tell ourselves 
we are immune to its effects, pretend it is not there or is not a 
problem, dismiss how it plays out in riots as "racial tension" or 
"mob psychology" or "inadequate law enforcement," and respond to its 
spreading use ineffectually - or not at all.

And abjectly grateful parents say of their drinking children, "At 
least they're not on drugs."

ANYONE WITH a sure-fire remedy would lead the charts as the planet's 
richest individual.

"Responsible drinking" may be almost as much an oxymoron as 
"responsible premarital (or non-marital) sex." In this country, the 
only way may be raising the drinking age to, say, 25 - which of 
course never is going to happen - and getting stricter with 
punishments (as we should with even initial drug use).

This is hardly an appeal for what Winston Churchill called - as he 
famously could - "intemperate self-restraint." Yet without a massive 
cultural change, which isn't going to happen either, it seems the 
nation's drinking problem is destined to grow worse. And we are to 
wince at its consequences and to read periodic observations such as 
these from two women - the first a Yale sophomore, the second
the lately late author (Caroline Knapp) of Drinking: A Love Story.

(1)"A large number of undergraduates at Yale are alcoholics . . . .I 
always have to laugh when my parents ask if anyone 'binge drinks' at 
Yale, because there isn't any other kind of drinking here. A good 
number of people start drinking around 9 p.m. and just keep going 
until they throw up, pass out, run out of alcohol, or manage to make 
it back to their room with the object of their desires, at which 
point they
are usually too drunk even to get their clothes off."

(2)"Tobacco has been vilified in this culture. The war on drugs is 
waged on illegal narcotics: crack, heroin, cocaine. Ecstasy is now 
enjoying its place in the spotlight, the social ill du jour. Alcohol, 
meanwhile, is abused by some 14 million Americans and contributes to 
the deaths of 100,000 each year. Our culture bottles it, buys it, 
uses it, glamorizes it, needs it. Perhaps we should start being honest
about it, too."

title: BRITISH DOCTOR KILLS 215 PATIENTS
words:
British Inquiry Finds Doctor Killed 215 of His Patients
By WARREN HOGE

HYDE, England, July 19  Dr. Harold Shipman, the suburban family 
doctor convicted two years ago of murdering 15 of his patients, 
actually killed at least 215 of them, an official investigation 
reported today.

The leader of the inquiry, Dame Janet Smith, a High Court judge, said 
the killing spree stretched over a 23-year period in which the 
gray-bearded, soft-spoken general practitioner built up a reputation 
for attentive and trustworthy medical care while systematically 
injecting the people in his care with lethal doses of the painkiller 
diamorphine. 

"He betrayed their trust in a way and to an extent that I believe is 
unparalleled in history," Dame Janet said. But officials said no 
further trials were likely. 

Reading from the findings of the yearlong inquiry in the hushed 
council chamber of Manchester Town Hall, Dame Janet said she also had 
"real cause" to suspect Dr. Shipman of killing 45 additional 
patients, but could not attach the same certainty to them as she 
could to the 200 new killings she reported. Of the 493 suspicious 
deaths beyond the 15 for which he was convicted, Dame Janet also 
found 210 to be due to natural causes and another 38 were 
indeterminable because of lack of evidence. 

"Deeply shocking though it is, the bare statement that Shipman has 
killed over 200 patients does not fully reflect the enormity of his 
crimes," Dame Janet said. "As a general practitioner, Shipman was 
trusted implicitly by his patients and their families." 

She continued: "Shipman's `nonviolent' killing seems almost more 
incredible than the violent deaths of which we hear. The way in which 
Shipman could kill, face the relatives and walk away unsuspected 
would have been dismissed as fanciful if it had been described in a 
work of fiction." 

The report said systems that should have safeguarded patients against 
misconduct of this scope had failed, and added that it was "deeply 
disturbing" his killings did not arouse suspicion for so many years.

While the 2,000-page report provided as conclusive a count of victims 
as will ever be known, Dame Janet said: "The true number of victims 
is far greater and cannot be counted. I include as victims the 
thousands of relatives, friends and neighbors who have lost a loved 
one or a friend before his or her time, in circumstances that will 
leave their mark for ever."

The report, a trial transcript and other information is online at 
www.the-shipman-inquiry.org.uk.
 
Prosecutors at Dr. Shipman's trial argued that his drive to kill was 
fueled by a desire for godlike power over life and death. But Dame 
Janet said her inquiry had been unable to come up with any easy 
explanation. Recalling that he had been convicted in his 20's for 
drug abuse, she said, "It is possible that he was addicted to 
killing."

The report turned up evidence that Dr. Shipman did seem to have a 
morbid interest in death; many of his victims were themselves in a 
state of recent bereavement. 

Judith Page, a patient of his who worked as a household helper, told 
investigators that Dr. Shipman once asked her if she had had the 
experience of finding a client dead. When she said "yes," he asked if 
it did not give her a "buzz."

According to the report, a Shipman killing would follow a typical 
pattern. He would call on an elderly patient, usually a woman living 
alone, on a weekday afternoon. Sometimes it was in response to a 
complaint of an ailment of some kind. Other times, it was presented 
as a routine checkup.

While there, Dr. Shipman would administer the deadly injection. Most 
of his victims were found sitting in their living room chairs, 
looking as if they had just fallen asleep. Sometimes he would stay on 
the scene and report the death to relatives himself. Other times, he 
would leave and wait to receive word, then return. 

In every case, he would have a ready explanation for the sudden death 
and would assure relatives that no autopsy was needed. In their 
shocked and bereaved state, the families would accept his word. 

Known for having a good bedside manner, Dr. Shipman could turn abrupt 
and flippant in the immediate aftermath of one of his killings. "When 
my mum died, he put his hand on my right shoulder and said, `I think 
I'll stay here a while in case she wakes up so she doesn't scare 
people,' " said Barry Swan, 52, a plumber whose mother, Bessie, 79, 
was murdered by Dr. Shipman in 1997. "I didn't think anything of it 
at the time, but I do now."

When he had just killed Mary Coutts in April 1997, the report said, 
her son and daughter-in-law asked him about the circumstances, and he 
said, "Well, I don't believe in keeping them going."

Hyde is a Manchester suburb of two- and three-story redbrick houses 
with a main street of small storefronts, one of which was the office 
where Dr. Shipman, now 56, ran his practice from 1992 until his 
arrest in 1998. Townspeople are still struggling to work out their 
feelings about having had England's most prolific serial killer in 
this otherwise unremarkable community.

Peter Wagstaff, 54, whose mother, Kathleen, 81, was a victim, said 
the doctor was "one of the most evil men in history" but added: "I do 
not think I have met anybody who said they hate him. It is just too 
difficult to understand and try to work out."

The families wonder at how they believed in Dr. Shipman. Fanny 
Nichols, 84, was murdered by Dr. Shipman in 1993, but her son Brian, 
58, a retired hospital worker, said today he was so trusting that he 
continued under Dr. Shipman's care even after being interviewed three 
times by the police. 

"When I saw the first newspaper story saying, `Hyde Doctor Under 
Investigation,' I remember saying, `Never in a month of Sundays is 
there any way that man could have done what they are saying,' " Mr. 
Nichols said. 

Though respected, Dr. Shipman was not popular. Today's report 
portrayed him as a man without real friends, someone who was a member 
of medical societies and other groups that usually produce social 
friendships but who remained a loner. He is the father of four 
children, and his wife, Primrose, has remained quietly steadfast, 
visiting him in prison in Durham. She has moved from Hyde and has not 
been seen in public.

Despite the new findings, the police say there will be no new 
prosecutions of Dr. Shipman because of the impossibility of finding 
jury members who have not heard of him. Dr. Shipman was jailed for 
life in 2000, and last week the home secretary, David Blunkett, 
declared that there would be no review of that sentence. 

Dr. Shipman maintained his innocence through his trial, and he has 
refused to discuss the case with detectives despite their repeated 
efforts. A copy of today's report is being sent to him.

No one here has much hope of ever getting an answer to the question 
posed by Jane Ashton-Hibbert, 35, whose grandmother Hilda was killed 
by Dr. Shipman. 

"I cannot reconcile the doctor I know who came to look after my 
sister and who delivered my daughter, to the doctor I know now, who 
has caused the betrayal of trust that has affected us all," she said. 
"The eternal question we live with in Hyde is, why did he do it ?" 

Dame Janet was asked if she thought the motive would ever become 
clear. "The short answer is no," she said. "Only he could answer that 
question, and at the moment it seems very unlikely he will."


New York Times, 7/20/02

title: BLESS YOUR PARENTS
words:
Preached by Dr. David M. Hughes
First Baptist Church
Winston-Salem, NC
May 9, 1999

THE BIG TEN - GOD'S RULES FOR THE GAME OF LIFE
RULE NO. 5:  BLESS YOUR PARENTS
Exodus 20:12

	
	The last thing Helen wanted to do was see her father.  You see, he 
had physically abused her throughout her childhood.  Helen's dad was 
an alcoholic who hugged  you one minute, and hit you the next.  The 
first chance Helen had to leave home, she was out the door. When her 
mom and dad divorced, Helen was confident she would never see her dad 
again, which was just fine with her.

	Then, Helen's life changed.  A co-worker introduced Helen to Jesus 
Christ, and Helen became a Christian.  She became involved in a 
church, and received lots of spiritual nurture from her fellowship.

	Over time, Helen noticed something interesting about her life.  In 
some areas, she was really growing, but in other areas, she was 
lagging behind badly.  She still had a tendency to criticize other 
people, and she still lost her temper in a hurry.  At first Helen 
thought she wasn't growing in these areas because she didn't have 
enough faith or didn't spend enough time in the Word.  

	Then one day, Helen discovered the root of her problem.  The problem 
was not a  lack of faith, or too little time in scripture.  The 
problem wasshe was not willing to honor her father.  For all her 
Christian growth, she still hated her father bitterly for the past, 
and she had not allowed God to heal that broken part of her life.  

	What really concerned Helen was that she realized that the older she 
got, the more she resembled the person she hated the mosther dad.  
Until she dealt with the stranglehold he had over her, she would 
continue to struggle in her spiritual life and personal relationships.

	Even after she understood her problem, Helen resisted the 
possibility of dealing with her dad.  Just thinking about him ripped 
her up inside.  But Helen eventually resolved to do something about 
her relationship with her dad, because she came to see that God 
honors those who honor their parents, and she was hurting herself 
more than anyone else by avoiding him.

	Where did Helen get the idea that God honors those who honor their 
parents?  From the fifth of the Ten Commandments, our focus on this 
Mother's Day.  Today we continue our series entitled The Big 
TenGod's Rules for the Game of Life.  Rule number five is, Honor 
your father and your mother.  Or put another way, Bless your parents.

	Notice that rule number five is a transitional commandment.  The 
first four commandmentsI am the Lord your God, and I shall be your 
only God; You shall have no substitutes for me; You shall not take my 
name in vain; Remember the Sabbath, and observe it faithfullydeal 
with our relationship with God.  The remaining six commandments deal 
with our relationships with other people in light of our relationship 
with God..

	Notice, too, that the commandment says we are to honor our fathers 
and mothers.  These days when Mother's Day is frankly a bigger deal 
than Father's Day, honoring mothers only seems natural.  But 3,500 
years ago when the Israelites first received the Big Ten, it was 
clearly a man's world, and for mothers to be mentioned at all is 
remarkable.  Even then, the Israelites understood that the birth of a 
baby involved a three-way partnership between God, a father, and a 
mother.  And to honor Dad without Mom would make no sense.

	But why should this commandment be fifth on the list?  Why should it 
take precedence over rules about murder and stealing?  What is so 
important about honoring parents, anyway?  
	The answer in a nutshell is this: the family is the cornerstone of 
civilization, and parents are the cornerstone of the family.  
Dishonor the parents and you've destroyed the family.  Destroy the 
family and you destroy civilization.  John Ruskin was right when he 
said that the history of the world is not the record of its great 
wars but the history of its households. God knew that for the 
Israelites or any nation to ultimately prevail, it's families had to 
prevail.  

	Even so, many of you have dreaded the sermon on this commandment 
more than any other because like Helen, your relationship with your 
parents is less than perfect.  Even on Mother's Dayespecially on 
Mother's Daywe are confused and even a little cynical about what it 
means to honor Mom and Dad.  Maybe you've seen that bumper sticker 
for parents that reads, Be nice to your children, they pick your 
nursing home.  And then there's the sticker for kids that says, Humor 
thy father and mother, they haven't written their wills yet.

	Even on Mother's Day, it's hard to cover over some of the nasty 
history we have with our parents, isn't it?  Even those of us who 
don't have alcoholics for parents usually have unpleasant memories of 
angry conflicts and confrontations.  How are we to honestly honor our 
parents if we are still sore about stuff from the past?

	Maybe the Apostle Paul can give us some help.  Paul repeats rule 
number five in Ephesians 6.  Children, obey your parents in the Lord, 
for this is right.  Honor your father and motherthis is the first 
commandment with a promise: so that it may be well with you and you 
may live long on the earth.  (Ephesians 6:1-3)

	Most commentators rightly point out that rule number five, contrary 
to what we may think, was originally targeted at adults rather than 
children.  Yes, you heard me right.  The original purpose of rule 
number five was to encourage Israelite adult children to give their 
senior adult parents their due.

	But Paul is also right when he understands that young children can 
also honor their parents by obeying them.  Most of this sermon will 
not be about how children should obey their parents and others in 
authority over them, like their teachers. But make no mistake about 
it, rule number five has plenty to say to those kids who have made 
Beavis and Butthead their role-models for how to disrespect and 
disobey their parents.  If you want to know at least one reason our 
high schools in America are in such turmoil right now, review the 
wisdom of rule number five which says, When respect for parents goes 
down the drain, respect for everything and everybody else goes, too. 

	But rule number five is first and foremost about adults honoring 
their fathers and mothers.  Paul reminds us rule number 5 is the 
first commandment with a promiseif we obey it, we are promised long 
and blessed lives.

	But what exactly does it mean to honor our parents?   The Hebrew 
word for honor means weighty.  Today, when the President or someone 
else of great importance speaks, we say their words carry a lot of 
weight.  Essentially, to honor others is to treat them as 
heavyweights, as persons of great significance.

	What's interesting is that the Hebrew word for curse means to make 
light of. In other words, we dishonor or curse others when act as 
though their words carry little weight.  To dishonor is to treat 
someone like a lightweight.  

	In Ephesians 6, Paul is echoing God's words in Exodus 20.  When we 
treat our fathers and mothers with the respect due persons of weighty 
stature, we not only honor them, we honor God.  And our lives will be 
blessed because we've blessed our parents.  But if we treat our 
parents lightly, like human lightweights, we dishonor God, and we 
diminish the quality of our own lives.  

	So how do we adult children honor our parents?  This is a question 
that causes many of us to struggle.  Does honoring our parents means 
always doing what they ask, even if what they ask is manipulative, or 
a violation of our personal integrity? Some people think so.  Does 
honoring our parents mean never placing them in retirement or nursing 
homes, but always moving them in with us when they can no longer fend 
for themselves?  Some people think so.

	Exactly how do we honor our parents? I have been helped on this 
question by a wonderful book called, The Blessing.  This book 
written, by Gary Smalley and John Trent, focuses primarily on the 
tremendous power of the blessing in scripture, and how parents can 
bless their children.  But there is one chapter devoted to adult 
children blessing their parents, and what follows comes from that 
chapter.  
	To honor our parents, says Smalley and Trent, is to bless them.  And 
one of the ways we bless our parents is through meaningful touch.   
This week I heard John Trent talk on a taped broadcast about Michael 
Reagan, the son of President Ronald Reagan.  Michael says that when 
he was young, his father would rarely hug him.  Michael knew his dad 
loved him, but his dad just wasn't a big hugger, and sometimes 
Michael wondered if his famous daddy cared for him.

	These days, Ronald Reagan suffers from Alzheimer's disease.  And 
Michael visits his dad regularly now.  He loves those visits even 
though his dad no longer recognizes him.  And the reason he loves the 
visits is because he now gives his dad big hugs, and his dad hugs 
back.  Michael believes that even though his dad's brain doesn't know 
who Michael is, his heart does.

	Some of us grew up with Moms and Dads who didn't hug.  But now, even 
though it may be awkward, we can honor them with our touch.

	Another way we bless our parents is with spoken words of love's 
affirmation.   Today, Mother's Day 1999, will be the busiest day for 
interstate phone calls this year.  The good news is, today millions 
of mothers will hear spoken words of love and support from their 
children.  The bad news is, many of those same mothers will have to 
wait a year before they hear again from their children.  And dads may 
have to wait longer than that.  

	I'm in the spoken word business.  You might call me highly 
verbal.  But I can get as tongue-tied as anybody else when it comes 
to speaking words of affirmation to my family.  I know, like you, 
that those three little words, I love you, can be the hardest to 
say.  And they are the ones we need to say most of all.

	We also bless our parents by walking with them through all of life's 
stages.  If they live long enough, the roles reverse, don't they?  
The children become the parents, and the parents become the 
children.  I've watched my parents parent their own parents.  I've 
watched them gradually take over their finances, place them in 
retirement homes, and manage their lives.  Even today, my father 
still cares for his 102 year old father.  And I am awed at what I 
have seen my parents, and many of you do for your parents.  

	But wait a minute, you say.  You've never met my parents.  They 
were complete jerks, and you can't possibly mean I'm supposed to 
bless them now!

	Notice that rule number 5 has no conditions or caveats.  As Dr. 
Laura Schlessinger, (In The Ten Commandments, p.144) observes, rule 
number five doesn't command us to [love] our parents.  Nor does it 
say we are to honor them only if they deserve it, or we feel like 
it.  The fact is, some of us may never have warm fuzzies around our 
parents for a complicated variety of reasons.  But we can still bless 
them if only in small ways, for two reasons:  they brought us into 
this world; and God tells us to. 

But wait a minute, you say.  My parents are dead.  And we ended up on 
lousy terms. What can I do now to bless my parents?  Plenty, say 
Smalley and Trent.  You can deal with your memories of your parents, 
which are likely still vivid.  One small suggestion.  Sit down a 
write a letter to each departed parent.  Say what you would say if 
you could talk in person.  Be as honest as you can be.  But search 
for ways to honor your parents with your words.  And if need be, 
discuss your letter with a Christian counselor.

	Fortunately for Helen, she got an opportunity to bless her dad in 
person.  She spoke with her pastor about her broken relationship with 
her father.  With his encouragement, she finally decided to try to 
see him.  From the pastor's office, she called her dad one afternoon, 
secretly praying her father would not be home.  After the fifth ring, 
her father answered the phone.  

	Hello, Dad?

	After a long silence on the other end, he replied, Helen?

	Helen told her dad she wanted to fly to his town and come see him.  
Her father immediately agreed.  Four days later, still quivering in 
her boots, Helen boarded a plane and flew to see her dad.  When she 
walked through his apartment door, she saw not the large, loud, 
beer-drinking man of her memories, but an old, tired-looking man. 
Sitting next to her dad on a couch, Helen poured out her heart to her 
dad.  She told him about becoming a Christian and how her life had 
changed.  And hardest of all, she confessed to her father how she had 
hated him for so many years.   Then she asked for his forgiveness.

	By now, both Helen and her father were in tears.  Helen's dad asked 
her to forgive him for all the terrible things he did to her as a 
child.  Finally, four hours later, just before she left, Helen hugged 
her dad and said those four words she never thought she'd hear 
herself say, I love you, Daddy.  

	And in that moment, she not only blessed her Daddy.  Her Heavenly 
Father blessed herimmeasurably.

title: BE FAITHFUL
words:
Preached by Dr. David M. Hughes
First Baptist Church
Winston-Salem, NC
May 23, 1999

                                              THE BIG TEN - GOD'S 
RULES FOR THE GAME OF LIFE
                                                                     
RULE NO. 7:  BE FAITHFUL

                                                                                  
Exodus 20:14

	Jason is a college student who took a class on leadership.  One day 
the class was talking about downsizing in the corporate world.  The 
professor asked the class if they had to downsize the Ten 
Commandments, what commandments would they eliminate. 

Jason reports that most of the students, including himself, thought 
the commandment not to commit adultery should be removed.  Why? 
Because this commandment is outdated, and nobody obeys it anywayso 
why have it?

	Is Jason and his college class right?  That's what we'll be 
exploring today as we continue our series on the Ten Commandments 
entitled, The Big TenGod's Rules for the Game of Life  Today our 
focus shifts to what is surely the least popular and most provocative 
of the Ten Commandments.  Rule number seven says, You shall not 
commit adultery.  Or put another way, Be faithful.  Be faithful to 
your marriage, yourself, your God.

	How could Jason's class reach the conclusion that rule number 7 
should be cut from the list?  Because, says Dr. Laura (Schlessinger), 
we live in an adultery culture.  In other words, we live in a 
culture that glamorizes, promotes, and defends having sexual 
relationships outside of marriage.  

	For decades now, Americans have been on the receiving end of a tidal 
wave of sex-saturated media that has all but normalized sex outside 
of marriage.  An article in Elle magazine tells us that an affair 
can be sexually recharging, an escape from a worn-out relationship, 
and a way into something better.  Movies like The Horse Whisperer 
make us cheer for infidelity despite ourselves, and make us feel 
disappointed that the wife doesn't leave her husband and live with 
Robert Redford happily ever after.  No less than Ted Turner, the 
founder of CNN, said just a few months ago that rule number 7 ought 
to be cut from the list.

	And sometimes it does seem like everybody else is doing it.  Surveys 
tell us that 30-40% of all married men, and 20-25% of all married 
women are unfaithful to their marriages sometime during their married 
lives.  Researchers also refer to the 70/70 phenomenon which holds 
that 70% of all men who earn more than $70,000 a year have affairs.  
What better example than our President, who makes 200 grand a year, 
and who recently had to confess inappropriate contact with Monica 
Lewinski?

	But the biggest contributor to our culture of adultery is our poor 
understanding of sexuality.  As Jim Dethmer says, today when school 
teachers provide sex education for children, they don't tell them too 
much.  They tell them too little.  By law our teachers have to 
confine themselves to the physical mechanics of sex.  So our kids 
wind up with a decent understanding of how sex works.  But they're 
often never told what sex means.

	Sometimes folks in church are squeamish about sex.  Not the Bible.  
It is explicit and eloquent on the subject.  Without a hint of 
embarrassment the Bible says that God created Adam and Eve, and they 
were naked and unashamed.  God provided Adam and Eve with sexual 
hormones and desires, and when he told them to be fruitful and 
multiply, they didn't say, Do we have to?!  

	But the Bible also makes it clear that when two people become one 
flesh, something very profound happens.  Their bodies fuse, but more 
importantly, their souls fuse, too.  That's what the Apostle Paul was 
trying to say in 1 Corinthians 6.  Our bodies aren't just glorified 
pieces of meat.  They are temples of the Holy Spirit.  And when we 
have sex with another, we are actually intermingling spirit with 
spirit, soul with soul.

	Jim Dethmer has a graphic illustration of this principle.  If you go 
outside in the dead of winter in sub-freezing temperatures and place 
your tongue on a metal pole, you'll leave a piece of your tongue 
behind if you try to pull away from the pole.  In the same way, every 
time you have sex with somebody, you leave a piece of your soul with 
them.   That's why Demi Moore couldn't have been more wrong in the 
movie Indecent Proposal.  As she ponders Robert Redford's offer to 
have sex with him for 1 million dollars, she tells her husband it 
won't be that big a deal because all she'll be giving Redford is her 
body, not her mind and her soul.  But what Demi and many people today 
miss is that you can't separate the body from the soul.

	Today people think that when two people have sex all that happens is 
that their bodies have intimate contact for a few minutes.  The truth 
is, when two people have sex their souls have intimate contact in a 
way that lasts for all eternity.  

	Now so far, I've made it sound like there's only one kind of 
adulteryphysical adulterybut that's not true.  

	Many of us, for example, have flirted with emotional adultery.  
We've never actually consummated a relationship with someone, but we 
have become very attached emotionally.  Jesus has emotional adultery 
in mind in Matthew 5:27-28 when he says, You know the commandment 
which says, Be faithful in marriage.  But I tell you that if you 
look at another woman and want her, you are already unfaithful in 
your thoughts.  

	Is it wrong for woman to take a second look at Brad Pitt, or a man 
to take notice of Julia Roberts?  No, it's only human for men and 
women to notice one another.  But when you begin to fixate on 
somebody, confide deep secrets to somebody, lean heavily on somebody, 
want somebody other than your spouse, you are into emotional 
adultery. 

	Spiritual adultery is a huge concern in scripture.  The book of 
Hosea in the Old Testament compares Israel to Hosea's wife Gomer, who 
is an adulterous prostitute.  The Hebrew word for adultery means to 
adulterate or contaminate, and spiritually it refers to adulterating 
our relationship with God by mixing other gods into our lives.  As a 
rule, those who commit physical adultery have already committed 
spiritual and emotional adultery.

	Today, psychologists also talk about cyber-adultery.  That is to 
say, many people are now cruising the Internet, stopping at 
pornographic web sites and chat rooms and conducting affairs through 
their computers and telephone.  The Internet contains some 28,000 
sites peddling almost 1 million pieces of pornographic information, 
generating a billion dollars of revenue a year.  Every year, more and 
more people leave marriages for cyber-mates, people they have met on 
their computers. There are lots of ways to leave your spouse, and 
cyber-adultery is one of them.

	What are the primary causes of adultery?  Anger is certainly on the 
list.  Years ago I heard Winston-Salem's own David Mace say in a 
conference on marriage that nothing destroys a marriage like 
unresolved anger.  Anger that festers between husband and wife can be 
like a cancer that eats away at the relationship.  A wife is sick and 
tired of the way or husband mistreats her.  Suddenly she finds a man 
who seems to understand her and value for who she is.  Before long, 
she's in the arms of that other man.

	Rebellion is another root cause of adultery.  Sometimes we just get 
tired of the rules and want to break free.  We begin to think that 
the wag who said monogamy was nothing more than monotony was exactly 
right.  There's something about forbidden fruit that makes it seem 
mighty fine.  And we find ourselves wanting to re-write the rules, 
and make our own rules as we go.  

	That's precisely what King David did.  He saw beautiful Bathsheba 
taking a bath, and he wanted her.  He said, Even though I'm not 
supposed to have her, I'm the king, and I'm going to have her.  And 
he did.

	What goes through our minds as we think about rewriting the rules?  
Just a lot of lies and rationalizations.  
	No one will ever know.
	There won't be any consequences
	I wasn't looking for an affairit just happened.
	We are soulmates.
	I have needs my spouse can't fulfill.
	I thought I was in love when I marriedbut this is the real thing.
	I've been under a lot of stress
	She/he really understands me.

	Maybe you are wrestling with these rationalizations right now.  If 
you are, just remember that these very rationalizations have ruined a 
lot of lives.

	Actually, I'm convinced that good, old-fashioned loneliness is the 
greatest cause of adultery.  Many a lonely soul has stared at 
pornographic pictures or videos, or reached out for another body in 
the hopes of curing loneliness.  But our deepest kind of soul 
loneliness cannot be cured by a picture, or a body.  Only one thing 
can ultimately cure this kind of soul loneliness, and that is an 
intimate relationship with the God. John Ortberg is right when he 
says the best way to keep our sexual energy properly harnessed and 
under control is to develop a close and intimate relationship with 
Jesus Christ.  No other substitute will do. 

	Somebody within the sound of my voice may be having sex outside of 
marriage (Yes, that includes sex between two unmarried people, 
too/adultery and fornication is one in the same), and you're still 
wondering why not.  Here are some pitfalls of adultery you may want 
to consider.  Having sex outside of an exclusive, permanent, and 
public relationship leads to a disconnection within yourself.  To use 
Jim Dethmer's image, you are leaving little pieces of your soul all 
over the place. Soon, you feel broken and fragmented inside, split 
off from yourself.

	You also feel disconnected from God.   It is very difficult, yea 
impossible, to feel intimate with God with you are being sexually 
intimate with the wrong person.  Anybody caught up in adultery or 
enslaved in pornography will tell you that fully and freely 
worshipping God is tough because the barrier of disobedience is 
there.  And to not be able to connect with God is a very lonely place 
to be.  

	Obviously, if you are being unfaithful to your marriage, you are 
disconnected to your spouse.  I've heard wives say that even when 
they are making love with their husbands their husbands seem far 
away.   Of course they are.  Their bodies may be temporarily 
together, but their souls are in some other bed.  

	Besides disconnection, destruction is the fruit of adultery.  
Proverbs 6:32 says He who commits adultery has no sense; he who does 
it destroys himself.  And, we might add, most everything he loves.  
How many children have been devastated, and families destroyed, by 
adultery?  Look at the number of children from broken homes today and 
all the problems they bring with them and ask yourself again, Is it 
true that adultery, the number one cause of divorce, is really no big 
deal?

	Recently, a successful professional was in my office.  He confessed 
to me that his infidelity destroyed his first marriage.  What finally 
made him stop and get counseling was not just that his infidelity was 
hurting his marriage or his kids. Finally, he realized his infidelity 
was destroying his soul, slowly but surely.  Adultery may look 
harmless to Jason and his classmates, to Ted Turner and Hollywood.  
But ask Bill Clinton just how destructive it can be.  There never has 
been, and there never will be a non-devastating affair.  

	Does remaining faithful to your spouse, yourself, your God have 
benefits?  You betcha!  It's hard work being faithful.  But fidelity 
pays in spades.

	Remaining true to your spouse assures that you will remain whole 
inside.  You will not be disconnected on the inside.  You will be 
whole.

	You will also keep your connection with the Lord strong.  This 
benefit is impossible to overstate.  Who can place a value on a 
conscience free from guilt!  To be able to come into God's presence 
and rejoice rather than retreat is worth more than all the gold at 
Fort Knox!

	You will also keep your connection with your spouse strong.  
Obviously, if you are not involved with someone else emotionally or 
physically, your own marriage has a better chance at growing strong.  
If you're having trouble with your spouse, don't bail out.  Get help.

	Some pastoral words, and we are done.
	If you have remained sexually pure your whole life, celebrate!  
Refuse to feel like an oddball just because the world seems to think 
you are old-fashioned and passe.  Rejoice that you are whole and 
connected to God in the best way possible.
	If you are currently engaged in sex outside of marriagepremarital 
sex, or extramarital sexconsider stopping immediately.  Make that 
phone call, write that letter, have that conversation in which you 
explain to your mister or mistress that you now understand adultery 
is a big deal, and it's time to stop.

	There's another category of people that I will not be able to give 
justice to today, but I will mention it anyway.  If you are someone 
who has been sexually abused, someone who has lost part of her soul 
involuntarily, don't despair.  Jim Dethmer puts it well when he 
reminds us that the God of the universe can perform soul surgery and 
return all the pieces of the soul, whether you gave them away 
voluntarily or they were taken by force.  Get Christian counseling if 
you need to, and hold on to the hope that God can heal you and make 
you whole.

	If you are someone who has sinned in this area, remember that the 
same Jesus who forgave the woman caught in adultery is ready to 
forgive you.  Sexual sin is not unforgivable sin.  If you will 
confess your sins, God is gracious, and will cast your sins into the 
deepest seas where they will be long-forgotten.

	A concluding thought.  You know what's beautiful?  Richard Burton 
and Elizabeth Taylor made a striking couple, but they eventually 
split.  Bruce Willis and Demi Moore made a striking couple, but they 
also split.  But a beautiful pair that came to my mind is E.E. and 
Ruth Phelps, long-time members of this church.  These days, Ruth 
Phelps lies dying of cancer, and E.E. visits her in the hospital 
faithfully.  You ask Ruth how she is doing, and all she can talk 
about is how her Sweetie E.E. will do after she is gone.  There 
they are, after 60 plus years of faithful marriage, hand in hand, in 
sickness in health, caring for each other until their last breath.

	That, my friends, is a thing of beauty!

title: BROKEN DRILL SLOWS RESCUE EFFORT
words:
Broken Drill Slows Rescue Effort for 9 Coal Miners
By FRANCIS X. CLINES     New York Times 7/27/02

QUECREEK, Pa., July 26  Stymied through the day after a drill 
snapped off in the rescue shaft, emergency crews labored tonight to 
resume their way down toward nine trapped coal miners, with no new 
signal that the men were still alive in the air pocket where they 
fled on Wednesday as a flood burst in on them.

"They know we're coming after them," Joseph A. Sbaffoni, chief of the 
State Bureau of Deep Mine Safety, insisted, even though the bit of 
the high-power drill broke off overnight about a third of the way 
down toward the miners.

The nine men are generally thought to be crouching in 50-degree water 
240 feet under the surface of the earth in a four-foot-high coal seam 
where they had raced to gasp for survival in a pocket of trapped air. 
Their location was determined when they tapped on the drill pipe that 
sunk a six-inch hole to the air pocket.

The miners had unexpectedly breached an abandoned mine that was 
thought to have been a safe distance away but turned out to be filled 
with millions of gallons of water that sent the men fleeing for their 
lives at 9:50 p.m. on Wednesday.

Workers spent an excruciating 14 hours of "fishing" for the broken 
drill bit 100 feet down the rescue shaft in hopes of retrieving and 
repairing it. But until this evening, their repeated efforts were in 
vain as the 1,500-pound bit slipped from a grappler and fell back 
down. 

The most hopeful estimates were that after drilling finally resumed 
at 8 o'clock tonight, rescuers would still need 7 to 10 hours to sink 
the 30-inch shaft to the men. After that would come an intricate 
rescue maneuver involving the use of an air lock at the top of the 
shaft to retrieve the men one by one in the face of decompression 
dangers.

A midday effort to use electronic sensors to hear further signs of 
life from the air pocket was pronounced inconclusive, because of the 
noise of nearby rescue equipment. The last clear tapping signals were 
heard on Thursday afternoon. 

Since 3 a.m. on Thursday, the air pocket has been steadily reinforced 
with compressed air delivered through an emergency six-inch pipe sunk 
to hold back the surrounding waters and deliver oxygen to the miners. 

In holding out hope for survival, rescuers prepared to deal with the 
threats of hypothermia from the cold, wet environment and the bends 
from the lengthy period of breathing compressed air, providing that 
the shaft reaches the men.

"We've got a long way to go," said Gov. Mark S. Schweiker as word was 
awaited that the drilling had resumed. Because of the broken drill, a 
second shaft was started this morning as a parallel escape route, 70 
feet beyond the first. It had reached just 40 feet down by 6 p.m. 

Watching from her farm where emergency specialists have worked around 
the clock since the disaster struck, Lori Arnold saluted rescuers who 
surrendered to catnaps under trees as they refused to leave the 
rescue patch of rolling pasture directly above the miners.

"When the drill broke this morning," Mrs. Arnold said, "one guy had 
to go tell the miners' families, and he was crying." 

"We're all stricken," she said of the eerie scene beyond her house, 
part pastoral with cows watering picturesquely, part desperate with 
rescue pumps and drills hammering away at the earth.

"We know some of the wives personally," she said. "They are part of 
this community, a place that is incredibly giving." 

Mrs. Arnold described sudden prayer vigils at her kitchen sink.

The rescue effort is particularly challenging because the waters 
flooded the passages around the miners to a level well above them, 
and the rescue shaft has to remain air locked from above to avoid 
exploding the pocket of compressed air upward and injuring the miners 
after the ceiling is breached.
Emergency pumping from 12 points to surface creeks finally began 
lowering the 50 million-gallon mass of water from the two mines, 
officials said. But the general level remained 10 feet above the 
miners at 6 p.m., with the pumps lowering the flood at the rate of a 
foot an hour. 

"We want to get that water below 1,830 feet," Mr. Sbaffoni 
emphasized, referring to the number of feet above sea level where the 
miners waited. 

That lowering of 10 more feet of water could occur by early morning, 
and it would ease the risk to the men when the shaft breaks through, 
the official noted. 

The news of the retrieved drill bit caused cheers and shouts among 
scores of relatives of the miners. They have been gathered in daily 
vigil, holding prayer circles at the Sipesville Fire Department. The 
relatives were kept removed from a throng of reporters and camera 
crews, whom the police threatened with arrest for any intrusions on 
the families.

This day of lost time and deep frustration was met with terse resolve 
from the rescue workers. 
"We've got to keep working," Mr. Sbaffoni said. "We need a little bit 
of luck."

Even if the men are reached and found alive, rescuers emphasized, 
there can be no sudden rush to the surface. An escape basket has been 
ready for the task, and rescuers practiced how to descend safely. 
Officials said the basket had to be lifted very slowly because of the 
risk of the bends, the formation of dangerous air bubbles in the 
bloodstream from fast decompression after breathing compressed air.
A Navy specialist at the mine, Capt. Henry Schwartz, said 
decompression would be required because the miners will have been 
living the equivalent of 40 feet under water for two days or more. 
Nine decompression chambers were ready.

Through this day of slim progress, rescue specialists cited disasters 
in which miners survived, including one flood in which survivors 
clung to life with their heads in air pockets for a week.
As he arrived here on Thursday, Mr. Schweiker buoyed the families by 
saying the 30-inch shaft might be sunk by as early as dawn today. But 
at 2:30 a.m., the bit's rod shaft snapped, halting the effort 140 
feet above the men.

"It could be 8 hours from now, it could be 12 hours from now," the 
governor estimated tonight."
The estimate of where the men ran to was confirmed when the air shaft 
broke early Thursday after engineers had mapped the most likely spot. 
No water rushed up, and the miners quickly tapped on the drill pipe 
to signal their survival.

Their air pocket is said to be in a mine corridor 48 to 52 inches 
high. The mined-out stretch would typically be 12 feet wide and 70 
feet long, although rescuers have no clear idea whether the crouching 
miners have much room for lateral movement.

For all the setbacks in drilling the rescue shaft, the most grievous 
problem was the lack of discernible tapping signals from below for 
more than a day. Privately, a friend of the trapped miners watching 
the rescue scene conceded to losing hope.

Mr. Schweiker paused at length in fielding a question about what the 
silence suggested. "Well," he gently responded, "it's a problem."

title: BASIC DOCUMENTS LACK CHRISTIAN CONNECTIONS
words:
Basic Documents Lack Christian Connections

Editor, Times-Dispatch: As a professor who regularly assigns works by 
Madison, Jefferson, Franklin, and Paine, I find recent letters on 
America's Christian essence both misinformed and dispiriting. 

One correspondent quotes the Constitution's insistence that "Congress 
shall make no law respecting an establishment of religion," and on 
the basis of this clause concludes, 

"There is no required so-called separation of church and state 
declared in the Constitution." The definition of "to establish" 
relevant here is not "to found," but, in the words of The Oxford 
English Dictionary, "to place (a church or a religious body) in the 
position of a state church." A church bearing Congress' seal of 
approval is precisely what the Constitution forbids. If that's not 
separation, what is?
Depictions of the Founders' generation as a uniformly pious lot are 
similarly misleading. Thomas Paine lumped together Christianity and 
Greek mythology, since both tell stories about gods who get women 
pregnant. He said so in print, and got into a lot of trouble.

Others were more circumspect. Jefferson privately re-wrote the 
Gospels, preserving the moral teachings of Jesus while cutting out 
references to his divinity, and founded a university not affiliated 
with a church, the first such institution the world had ever known.

A rather vague being referred to as "Nature's God" and "divine 
Providence" does make cameo appearances in the Declaration of 
Independence, but Providence shows up in the Constitution only as a 
city in Rhode Island.

Both documents would have a very different flavor if phrases like 
"Jesus Christ" appeared in them, and those who imagine that the 
United States was set up as a fundamentally Christian country have to 
tell us why the Founders somehow failed to mention it. One thing is 
clear. If the founding documents of our nation were accused of being 
Christian, there wouldn't be enough evidence to convict them. Thomas 
Peyser. Richmond.

title: BELIEF IN MIRACLES REQUIRES TRUST
words:
Aug 10, 2002

Belief in miracles requires trust, accepting the unknown

STACY HAWKINS ADAMS
INSPIRATIONS 

Even among people who believe in God, differences of opinion are 
common.

Take the matter of miracles, for example.

I asserted in a column last week that we should consider as miracles 
the July 28 rescue of nine men from a flooded Pennsylvania mine, as 
well as many daily occurrences we often take for granted.

I intimated that rather than good fortune, miracles are blessings 
delivered in God's way and God's timing.

Many readers agreed.

They shared details of situations in which a miracle saved lives. 
They expressed gratitude for the reminder not to disregard life's 
simple gifts.

But some found the column disturbing.

They believe in God, they said, but question whether it's accurate to 
credit him with performing modern-day feats.
If God is in the miracle-making business, one reader asked, why does 
he do it so selectively?

Why didn't he save 5-year-old Samantha Runnion of California from 
being kidnapped and murdered by a former neighbor?

Why didn't he intervene before terrorists killed seven people, 
including five Americans, at Hebrew University in Jerusalem nine days 
ago?

Why does God allow good people to die young and individuals who have 
committed terrible deeds to continue living?

How do you explain being in the wrong place at the wrong time?

I'll readily admit that I don't have the answers. And I know how it 
feels to be in the center of a storm, unable to immediately see how 
God can produce a miracle from the circumstances, either for me or 
for someone else.

But my personal belief - that the Creator is wise, powerful and 
benevolent enough to decide when and how best to intervene in a 
situation - is a matter of faith.

Still, the questions deserved a response, because they're the kind of 
issues I, and others who believe in miracles, wish we understood.

We fret over the violence and evil occurring around the world just 
like others. We question why bad things happen to good people, and 
vice versa.

Yet many of us accept that it is beyond our human ability to 
understand God's motivations.

"We find ourselves in the 21st century in a world in which everything 
has an explanation and everything is measurable and can be calculated 
and, we believe, everything can be understood," said Rabbi Merrill 
Shapiro, leader of Congregation Or Atid, a Jewish synagogue in 
Henrico County.

"But God is well beyond that realm," Shapiro said. "To think we can 
understand why God takes the life of a 25-year-old, or even a 
2-year-old, or why God created conjoined-at-the-head twins is 
arrogant or egotistical of us. It's also arrogant of us to think we 
can second-guess God or understand why God does one thing and not the 
other."

Indeed, a longtime friend who has suffered for the past year with a 
crippling and painful ailment told me after the column ran that she 
still experiences miracles, despite her daily struggle.

"What people fail to realize is, it's the mountains that bring you 
closer to God," she said. In tackling those mountains, she said, we 
often encounter miracles.

And if we'll allow it, we can be used by God to help give life to the 
miraculous.

"One of the miracles God created was human beings that have free 
will," Shapiro said. "Evil comes into the world through the hands of 
human beings who make the wrong choices.

"The rescuers of the nine miners could have chosen to stay home with 
their families, go out to eat at a restaurant, watch TV or go to a 
movie, but they made good choices," he said. "They said, 'This is 
what is important,' so they brought good to the world."

The message? To believe in miracles is to believe in the power of an 
unseen God to orchestrate and deliver his blessings in his divine 
wisdom.

It requires us to blindly trust him.

It requires us to accept that there are some things we may never 
understand while we live on earth.

But if we can believe that God performs miracles, even when we don't 
see one on the horizon, we can believe that somehow, he'll yield 
fruit from a tragic or heartbreaking situation.

That fruit could be an overflowing goodness from mankind, like that 
seen after the Sept. 11 terrorist attacks, when strangers befriended 
one another and people from across the nation filled coffers with 
donations to help survivors and grieving families.

The fruit could be a person's discovery of his or her ability to 
persevere through challenges and in the process, become more mature.

The fruit could be an unexpected blessing from an unexpected source, 
or a person's newfound zest for life.

According to biblical Scriptures, one cannot view situations from a 
spiritual perspective without opening one's heart to faith.

Yet even when we do so, we must accept that attempting to know God's 
ways is a never-ending process.

As we continue to seek him, however, we'll become better at detecting 
miracles in the making, even amid trials.

As one reader put it, "We just need to be aware and listen."


Contact Stacy Hawkins Adams at (804) 649-6578 Richmond Times Dispatch

title: BAPTISTS:PARADOX PEOPLE WITH A PERSONAL FAITH
words:
Baptists: Paradox people with a personal faith

 By James M. Dunn

 A handsome, stocky, youngish man tapped on my office door. (Now that 
I'm 70, everyone is
 youngish.) Turns out he had come to my nest in the steeple of Wait 
Chapel, high above the
 Wake Forest University campus, to see if he and his teenage son 
could go on up higher in the
 tower. They couldn't.

 But then he confessed to being a Missouri Synod Lutheran pastor and 
politely began asking
 questions about our divinity school. I probably told him more than 
he wanted to know. He, trying
 to wrap up the conversation and extricate himself, said: "So, you'd 
say that the divinity school is
 conservative."

 "No," I said, "we couldn't rightly be called liberal or 
conservative. We're Baptist, and that's
 neither."

 Reflecting on that answer, I remembered Brooks Hays' response to a 
query about whether he
 was liberal or conservative. "We are all both," he said. "Take my 
old dog, Fergus, here. He's
 liberal when he chases a rabbit, but conservative when he buries a 
bone."

 Brooks was right. At times we are either or neither or both. That is 
very Baptist.

 I am persuaded there is a Baptist way of being Christian; that there 
is something distinctly
 Baptist in the way we do theology and ethics and politics. We call 
it "soul freedom."

 It avoids the Manichean dualism that plagues Western thought. It 
overshoots the
 "it's-gotta-be-this-or-that" mentality. It has a capacity for 
ambiguity that leaves room for faith
 and promotes wholeness, not fragmentation. It does not fear 
ambivalence, but humbly accepts
 that dimension of the human condition. It gives us a chance to face 
a world that is no longer
 black and white, but comes at us in living color.

 The baptist beast has some distinctive markings in the Christian 
zoo. Neither liberal nor
 conservative, but Baptist, may be our secret weapon, our answer to 
the heart hunger of lots of
 folks who seek immediacy, honesty, reality in religion. That's the 
question, isn't it?

 Martin Marty in a watershed article in 1983, "Baptistification Takes 
Over," noted the trend in this
 country "to zero in on the key issue that modernity poses for 
religion: choice." A decade later in
 an insightful book, The American Religion, Harold Bloom hit the same 
note and affirmed the
 competence of the individual before God as a distinctly Baptist 
theme and a hallmark of this
 nation's religious ethos.

 Bloom, America's premier literary critic, stepped off his usual turf 
to describe what he takes to
 be a peculiarly American religion that insists upon "soul competency 
[that] destroys
 fundamentalism ... sanctioning endless interpretive possibilities." 
Sounds pretty baptist to me.

 In his "baptistification" piece Marty pled for both the churchly or 
catholic approach and the
 sectarian or baptistic way of doing religion. Marty sees the two 
sides as opposite, but always
 complementary forces. He contends that the baptist side calls for 
choice, individual freedom,
 decision and knowing who one is in the family of faith -- as Bill 
Moyers says, "a grown-up's
 religion." On the catholic side one is born into one's church.

 Marty sees the two approaches coexisting because the Holy Spirit 
needs both. Without this
 complementarity, Marty sees one's faith as incomplete. He pleads for 
both catholic and baptist
 styles because "both draw on the common Christian story of God's 
activity in Jesus Christ,
 witnessed to by the power of the Holy Spirit in the Scriptures and 
in the testimony of believers.
 We need both styles to be healthy, open, developing and interactive."

 Baptists have always dealt in dyads: General and Particular, 
Separate and Regular,
 independent and interdependent, truth and freedom, sola scriptura 
and sola fide. We have
 been necessarily dialogical. We were dialectical before being 
dialectical was cool. Some may
 even say diabolical, always fussing and fighting over contradictions.

 We need not fear contradictions. According to a recent Newsweek 
article, "the contradictions in
 Jesus' legacy are thick and epic. In defeat there is victory; in 
humility, strength; in surrender,
 gain; in darkness, light. All counterintuitive ideas."

 So whether we talk about paradox, mystery, complementarity, conflict 
or contradictions, we
 have to deal with tensions between our freedoms and our beliefs.

 We hold a faith that is PERSONAL rather than propositional, 
EXPERIENTIAL rather than
 academic, DYNAMIC rather than static, ACTIVE rather than passive, 
and LIVELY rather than
 dead-letter.

 According to Ansbro, the academic agenda for Martin Luther King Jr. 
when he went to Boston
 was to champion the personal: a personal God, a personal faith, a 
personal theology. He saw
 the church as "beloved community." Tillich turned him off. He was 
not interested in propping up
 faith with propositions.

 Our baptist brand is not so much liberal or conservative as 
PERSONAL. We sing with the
 Apostle Paul "I know whom I have belived," not "I know what I have 
believed."

 Experience was a key for E.Y. Mullins, a Massachusetts pastor who 
knew and appreciated Will
 James. His 1908 book, Axioms of Religion, written for American 
Baptists, became the classic
 definition of what it means to be Baptist: a symphony of freedom.

 In fact, Bloom, in the book mentioned above, nominates Edgar Young 
Mullins as the "Calvin or
 Luther or Wesley of Baptists ... the definer of their creedless 
faith." Bloom believes that "Mullins
 is the most neglected of major American theologians. Pragmatically, 
he is more important than
 Jonathan Edwards, Horace Bushnell and the Niebuhrs because [he] ... 
formulated the faith of a
 major American denomination."

 Mullins' central contribution was the concept of the competence of 
the individual before God, or
 EXPERIENTIAL religion. We say with the man born blind: "Whether he 
[Jesus] is a prophet or
 not, I know not. One thing I do know, that I was blind but now I 
see."

 Dynamic and dissenting, not static, describes the biblical doctrine 
of Baptists. For Bloom,
 Mullins sets out the baptist way. For him, "the weird metaphor of a 
'liberal' or 'inerrant' reading
 totally vaporizes." Every believer has the right and responsibility 
of personal interpretation. This
 dialectical tension has cursed and blessed baptists from our 
beginnings. We have never been
 very good at accepting creeds or norms.

 "Choose ye this day" could read for us, "choose ye each day." There 
is a volitional and
 therefore cognitive aspect to our faith. We have to keep on deciding 
to follow Jesus. It is the
 "awful burden of freedom" of which Brunner spoke.

 Samuel Stillman was the only Massachusetts Baptist minister listed 
among the 118 members of
 a society for the abolition of slavery. Yet he owned at least one 
slave, Jephthah, his body
 servant. Stillman could preach an artillery sermon and other 
patriotic stemwinders for the
 American revolution and at the same time passionately support a 
separation of church and
 state. To quote Emerson, "A foolist consistency is the hobgoblin of 
little minds, adored by little
 statesmen and philosophers and divines." Being baptist means we are 
still trying to decide.

 We respond to Bonhoeffer's insistence that no one can possess the 
Word of God for a single
 instant other than in the doing of it. Ours is a practiced faith, 
ACTIVE, not merely an academic
 exercise. Missionary, maybe too much. Moral, maybe moralistic. 
Evangelistic, even
 proselytizing. Ethical, often pontifical in our certainty, but 
active. Our hyperactive faith may look
 liberal or conservative depending on what you're compared to. In 
John 7:17, Jesus challenged
 searchers: "If any ... will do his will, he shall know the doctrine 
whether it be of God."

 The "lively experiment" entered into by Roger Williams when he was 
banished from
 Massachusetts had much in common with baptistness. To paraphrase 
Buckminster Fuller,
 Baptist is a verb. We "baptist." We are more a process, a journey, a 
movement than an
 organized religion or an institution.

 We are always juggling, always struggling. Ed Gaustad, speaking of 
Roger Williams' "lively
 experiment," suggests that Williams was "out to do nothing less than 
alter the institutional
 structure of the Western world." LIVELY! Sounds pretty liberal, but 
some consider following any
 17th century white European male decadently conservative. But, it's 
quick and powerful and
 sharper than a two-edged sword -- this faithful freedom.

 So, maybe a baptist alternative to the TULIP of constipated 
Calvinists of the five-principle sort
 would be PEDAL, for a faith that is personal, experiential, 
dissenting, active and lively.

 But living such a fluid faith, not neatly creedal, seldom 
politically correct, makes extreme
 demands. We need an extra dose of modesty and humility that is born 
of a biblical awareness
 of our sin and fallibility and frailty. We must pray for the wisdom 
that only God can give. We will
 surely be tempted and tried and oft made to wonder why it should be 
thus all the day long.

 So what if being Baptist calls us to fight pigeonholing and to 
resist libel by label?

 What does it mean to this generation of Baptists that some of us 
refuse to be called
 "evangelical" unless you let us define the word?

 What does it do for pluralism if we claim that anyone's religious 
liberty denied means that
 everyone's religious liberty is in danger?

 What does it matter that one reason Baptists have always stood firm 
for separation of church
 and state is that we have room for liberals and conservatives of all 
sorts and are convinced that
 neither church nor state have any business messing with our personal 
relationships to God?

 I may admire, learn from and stand in awe of conservatives cut from 
theological or political
 templates, but I cannot be one. That does not mean I'm content to be 
labeled liberal. I insist on
 being free to be either, neither or both. Just tag me a Baptist with 
a capital "B.".

 Perhaps our best contribution is to be who we have been, to dissent, 
to be ourselves, to greet
 tension and with energy turn it creative, to suffer because the more 
we know the joy of
 freedom, the more we hurt.

 (James M. Dunn is Visiting Professor of Christianity and Public 
Policy at Wake Forest University
 Divinity School and retired executive director of the Baptist Joint 
Committee on Public Affairs.
 This article is adapted from a presentation he made for the 200th 
anniversary of the
 Massachusetts Baptist Missionary society of American Baptist 
Churches of Massachusetts.)
